column15: VLAN ID 896–4094 couldn’t pass through the local  loop QinQ link due to two VLAN ID lists configured in the QinQ. The system only recognized the first list (VLAN ID 2-894). This configuration was made after a request from the Herza Team to pass VLAN 895 through the QinQ link during a CAC trial service.
column16:
1.	Herza Team moved traffic to VLAN ID range 500 — result: Normal.
2.	ABHINAWA Team asked Herza to test using VLAN 894 and 896 — result: VLAN 894 passed, VLAN 896 failed

column15:
Issue was caused by a fiber optic (FO) cable 
being cut in main link and circuit auto reroute to 
backup link, which resulted in a intermittent.
column16:
Resplice fiber optic by vendor and the link has 
been restored to normal.

an inverter malfunction, which subsequently 
caused battery damage.

from the PLN side (temporary)

column15:
The local-loop segment of the DCI-CYBER1 link was 
disrupted due to a broadcast from one of the OIXP 
members. This caused the Metro switch to become 
overloaded, with resource utilization reaching 100%.
column16:
1. The Metro provider team shut down the 
interconnection link to OIXP. 
2. OIXP admin identified and shut down the source of the 
broadcast.

column15: Load balancing on the Jakarta-Singapore backbone was interrupted due to instability in one of the backbone cables, temporarily affecting ingress traffic to customer prefixes in Jakarta.
column16:
o The primary upstream provider disabled load balancing and 
redirected traffic through a stable path to avoid the affected 
cable. 
o Repairs on the unstable cable are ongoing and have been 
escalated to the principal by the primary upstream provider. 
o ABH NOC migrated ingress traffic to another upstream 
provider to maintain stability until the primary provider 
resolves the issue.

column15:
1. Theres an issue occurred on the Singapore–Jakarta backbone 
of upstream provider 1, which impacted international ingress 
traffic to several OWS prefixes in Jakarta. 
2. There is asymmetric routing between ingress and egress paths 
across two different upstream providers.
column16:
1. The upstream provider escalated the backbone issue to their 
cable provider. 
2. ABH applied prefix prepending for many OWS prefixes toward 
the affected upstream provider 1 to shift both inbound and 
outbound traffic to the upstream provider 2.

column15:
1. The cable detached from the dead-end, resulting in damage to the cable jacket at KM 18 from Bahomahoni.
2.  There is a high bending at KM 10 from TS Matano.
column16:
Action 1: 1. Conducting OTDR measurements
                  2. Tracing route and splicing FO cable


Action 2:  1. Conducting OTDR measurement
2. Route tracing for CP
                    3. Resplice core due to high bending

column2:
Aofei-Domestic
Tencent-ISC
Aofei Jakabare + NEU<>CYBER
Aofei Indigo
column15:
The outage was caused by an issue with the MCB that failed/trip 
due to a worn thermal mechanism. We suspect this may have 
been triggered by a power spike or general wear over time
column16:
1. The faulty MCB was immediately replaced with a new unit 
2. We powered off and redistributed some equipment to reduce 
the risk of further power spikes

column15: During scheduled maintenance activity CHG0079089 ( ISPL TICKET NUMBER #2025-0030258), customer loads were transferred to generator power. While performing the maintenance, the UDU breaker for 6A Colo 1 and 2 tripped, resulting in a loss of power to affected customers.
column16: Equinix IBX Site Staff have restored power to the 6A Colo 1 and 2 B-side PDUs, and customer loads have been successfully transferred to the B-side PDUs.
